comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: At this link: In Book ‘THE WAR STORY OF OLIVER HOLMES WOODWARD, CAPTAIN, 1st AUSTRALIAN TUNNELLING COMPANY, AUSTRALIAN IMPERIAL FORCE’, James is mentioned as a senior member of the Hill 60 firing party on 7 June 1917:- My last tour of ordinary duty on Hill 60 extended from 20th to 25th May, and on 21st May Captain Worlledge, of the Royal Engineers Depot at Chatham, arrived on Hill 60 to finally check the Mine leads. He made independent tests on the Mine leads, examined all details in connection with the proposed method of firing the Mines, and after an exhaustive examination approved of all plans. The arrival of Captain Worlledge indicated that the long expected attack was close at hand, and the realisation of this seemed to unconsciously add to the strain.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
June 20th 1904, at Wellington College Speech Day , J. P. G. Worlledge won prizes for
1. Freehand Drawing (Mathematical School) 2. Geometrical Drawing 3. The Pender Prize for an Essay on a Natural History Subject
Incidentally, the guests included King Edward and Queen Alexandra, the Duke of Connaught, Prince John of Glucksburg, the Archbishop of Canterbury, the Bishop of Oxford, and four column inches of assorted, Lords, Ladies, Generals, Sirs, etc (including 2 V.C.s). The last name in the list is the Superintendent of Broadmoor.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] In his mother's death notice in February 1905, she is described as the widow of the late Major Albert Cranworth Worlledge, so it couldn't be his father's horse. Perhaps he was squandering his inheritance on the horses. He also had a horse called Prestige running in the Moderate Hurdle Race at Gatwick on 7th January 1911 and at Birmingham the following week, and also one called St Elmo at Lingfield the following month. All his horse-racing activity seems to have been concentrated in late 1910 and early 1911. Perhaps just a passing phase.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: At the start of World War II, Vernon Kell, the head of MI5, introduced a contingency plan to deal with the problem of illicit radio transmissions. A new body was created, the Radio Security Service (RSS), headed by Major J.P.G. Worlledge, who until 1927 had commanded a Wireless Company in Palestine. Worlledge's brief was to "intercept, locate and close down illicit wireless stations operated either by enemy agents in Great Britain or by other persons not being licensed to do so under Defence Regulations, 1939". As a security precaution, the RSS was given the cover designation of MI8(c).

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
Research Article
Journal of Navigation
Journal of Navigation (1949), 2 : pp 82-83 
Copyright © The Royal Institute of Navigation 1949

Errors in Observed Altitudes
Colonel J. P. G. Worlledge
The calculation and publication of the errors in measured altitudes due to tilt of the sextant serve a useful purpose in impressing users more strongly with the need for care than does the unbacked advice to rock the sextant always given in the text-books, and also in indicating that carelessness carries greater penalties the greater the altitude. The work once done is done for ever, so we may as well get the sum right.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: A check on the Munster Express says that the 15th is not the date we're looking for after all. On that date, the 16th Signal Company of the Royal Engineers marched out of the city with their wagons, heading for Carrick, and then Mallow: No more striking example of the changed attitude of the Irish people towards the army could be evinced than was witnessed on Thursday morning in the city, when the Barrack Street Brass Band accompanied the men of the 16th Signalling Company, Royal Engineers, who for several months past have been training in the barracks, Waterford. The men, about 250 in number, left that morning for Mallow to complete their training before being sent to the Front.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
A digression: It struck me that JPGW (with his RMA contemporaries) was born just at the right time to serve during Great War, and, being a career army officer, would still be serving in 1939 at the outbreak of the next unpleasantness. He made it through both, and as his contemporaries at the RMA (Gentlemen Cadets, as the London Gazette describes them) who went into the Royal Engineers have such distinct and googlable names, I thought I'd see how they got on. Those I found:
Frederick Vavasour Broome Witts CBE DSO MC reached the rank of general. retired in 1943. d 1969 Frederick Hermann Kisch became a leading figure in the ZIonist movement in the 1930s. Returned to active service and was killed while inspecting a minefield in Tunisia in 1943. Julian Missenden Smeathman died in October 1914 in Flanders. No known grave. Eric Herbert Clarke Awarded the Military cross in 1918, but was killed before the end of the war. Meyrick Bingham Whistler Smith-Rewse died in 1915 Alleyne Frank Chater reached the rank of Colonel and died in 1969 Herman Cyril -McNeile won an MC and rose to Lt-Col, but left the army in 1919 to concentrate on his career as a best-selling author. Wrote the Bulldog Drummond books, died 1937 Francis Henry Budden rose to Lt-Col. Wrote 'Railway Statistics And The Operating Officer'. died 1953 Essex Barry Fox Lt-Col. died 1955 Clement Preedy Major. OBE in 1919 in connection with military operations in Mesopotamia. Died 1965

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Searched for J.P.G. Worlledge in the Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, but no sign of him. Ditto for the Irish Dictionary of Biography. Then searched in the Irish Newspapers Archive, and J.P.G. turned up all over the place in connection with horse racing, e.g.: Irish Independent, 15th March 1912 - Irish Army Point-to-Point Races at Ellistown, near Kildare - Mr. J.P.G. Worlledge's (R.E.) Cyclops ran. Kildare Observer, 23rd March 1912: ... leaving Little Rover, who had fallen early in the contest, but was quickly remounted by his owner, Mr R. Wyndham-Quin, of the 12th Lancers, to achieve a ready victory from Mr J.P.G. Worlledge - a well-known young Engineer owner and rider between the flags - mounted on his own Cyclops... Also found his wedding photo in the Freeman's Journal on 21 March 1921. Caption said: "The marriage between Captain J.P.G. Worlledge, O.B.E., Royal Corps of Signals (late Royal Engineers), and Sibyl Maud, younger daughter of T.D. Atkinson, D.L., and Mrs. Atkinson, of Glenwilliam Castle, Co. Limerick, took place on St. Patrick's Day at Christ Church, Dun Laoghaire. (Left to right) T.D. Atkinson, Esq.; Capt. Carter, Capt. Worlledge and his Bride, Mrs. T. Durbin Atkinson, Capt. and Mrs. Dewer, Royal Navy; and Miss Pimm. Miss Pimm and Capt. Carter were bridesmaid and best man, respectively." Infuriating that the photo quality is atrocious, as I'd have loved to see what J.P.G. looked like...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: I wonder if Mr R. Wyndham-Quin is in fact Richard Southwell Windham Robert Wyndham-Quin (18 May 1887 – 28 August 1965). Just when you thought you'd seen the most unlikely names, you come across a person with 2 different spellings of the same word in his name.
